"**Those Were the Days** " is a song credited to [Gene
Raskin](/wiki/Eugene_Raskin "Eugene Raskin"), who put a new English lyric to
the [Russian romance](/wiki/Russian_romance "Russian romance") song "Dorogoi
dlinnoyu" ("Дорогой длинною", literally "By the long road"), composed by
[Boris Fomin](/wiki/Boris_Fomin "Boris Fomin") (1900–1948) with words by the
poet [Konstantin Podrevsky](/wiki/Konstantin_Podrevsky "Konstantin
Podrevsky"). It deals with reminiscence upon youth and romantic idealism.

[Mary Hopkin](/wiki/Mary_Hopkin "Mary Hopkin")'s 1968 version of the song,
produced by [Paul McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney"), became a
number one hit on the [UK Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles
Chart"). The song also reached number two on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"), behind McCartney's own band
[The Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles")' hit "[Hey Jude](/wiki/Hey_Jude
"Hey Jude")". In France the song was at no. 1 in the very first edition of the
singles sales chart launched by the Centre d'Information et de Documentation
du Disque in October 1968.[3]

## Early
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Those_Were_the_Days_\(song\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Early history")]

[Georgian](/wiki/Georgians "Georgians") singer [Tamara
Tsereteli](/wiki/Tamara_Tsereteli "Tamara Tsereteli") (1900–1968) and
[Russian](/wiki/Russians "Russians") singer [Alexander
Vertinsky](/wiki/Alexander_Vertinsky "Alexander Vertinsky") made what were
probably the earliest recordings of the song, in 1925[4] and in 1926[5]
respectively.

The song appears in the 1953 British/French movie _[Innocents in
Paris](/wiki/Innocents_in_Paris "Innocents in Paris")_ , in which it was sung
with its original Russian lyrics by the Russian [Tzigane](/wiki/Romani_music
"Romani music") [chanteuse](/wiki/Chanteuse "Chanteuse") Ludmila Lopato. [Mary
Hopkin](/wiki/Mary_Hopkin "Mary Hopkin")'s 1968 recording of it with Gene
Raskin's lyric was a chart-topping hit in much of the Northern Hemisphere. On
most recordings of the song, Raskin is credited as the sole writer, even
though he wrote only the later English lyrics (which are not an English
translation of the Russian lyrics) and not the music.

## Later
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Those_Were_the_Days_\(song\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Later history")]

In the early 1960s Raskin, with his wife Francesca, played folk music around
[Greenwich Village](/wiki/Greenwich_Village "Greenwich Village") in New York,
including [White Horse Tavern](/wiki/White_Horse_Tavern_\(New_York_City\)
"White Horse Tavern \(New York City\)"). Raskin, who had grown up hearing the
song, wrote with his wife [6] new English lyrics to the old [Russian
music](/wiki/Music_of_Russia "Music of Russia") and then copyrighted both
music and lyrics in his own name.[7] [The Limeliters](/wiki/The_Limeliters
"The Limeliters") subsequently released a recording of the song on their 1962
LP _Folk Matinee_.[8] The Raskins were international performers and had played
London's "Blue Angel" every year, always closing their show with the song.
[Paul McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney") frequented the club
and being quite taken with the song he attempted to get several singers or
groups (including the early [Moody Blues](/wiki/The_Moody_Blues "The Moody
Blues")) to record it.[9] Failing at that, after the formation of [the
Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles")' own [Apple
Records](/wiki/Apple_Records "Apple Records") label, McCartney immediately
recorded Mary Hopkin performing the song. The song was eventually recorded in
over twenty languages and by many different artists, including Gene and
Francesca, and Raskin was able to live very well on the royalties, buying a
home in Pollensa, [Mallorca](/wiki/Majorca "Majorca"), a [Porsche
Spyder](/wiki/Porsche_550 "Porsche 550") and a sail boat.

Hopkin's recording was produced by [Paul McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul
McCartney") with an arrangement by [Richard
Hewson](/wiki/Richard_Anthony_Hewson "Richard Anthony Hewson") (per the label
of the record) and became a number-one hit on the [UK Singles
Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart"). In the United States,
Hopkin's recording reached number two on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") (held out of the top spot
for three weeks by "[Hey Jude](/wiki/Hey_Jude "Hey Jude")" by [the
Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles")) and topped the Billboard [Easy
Listening](/wiki/Adult_Contemporary_\(chart\) "Adult Contemporary \(chart\)")
charts for six weeks.[10] In the Netherlands, it topped the charts for two
consecutive weeks.[11] The Russian origin of the melody was accentuated by an
instrumentation that was unusual for a top-ten pop record, including
[balalaika](/wiki/Balalaika "Balalaika"), [clarinet](/wiki/Clarinet
"Clarinet"), [hammered dulcimer](/wiki/Hammered_dulcimer "Hammered dulcimer"),
tenor banjo and children's chorus, giving a [klezmer](/wiki/Klezmer "Klezmer")
feel to the song. Mary Hopkin played acoustic guitar on the recording, and
[Paul McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney") also played acoustic
guitar and possibly percussion. The hammered dulcimer, or
[cimbalom](/wiki/Cimbalom "Cimbalom"), was played by Gilbert Webster.[12] It
is unknown who played the banjo though McCartney is known to be a banjoist.

McCartney also recorded Hopkin singing "Those Were The Days" in five other
languages for release in their respective countries:

  * In [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain"), _Qué tiempo tan feliz_ , by [Rosa Morena](/wiki/Rosa_Morena "Rosa Morena") (instead of _Aquellos Fueron Los Días_ or _En Aquellos Días_)
  * In [West Germany](/wiki/West_Germany "West Germany"), _An jenem Tag_
  * In [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy"), _Quelli erano giorni_
  * In [France](/wiki/France "France"), _Le temps des fleurs_
  * In [Afghanistan Farsi](/wiki/Dari_language "Dari language"), "Deegar Ashkam Mariz" by legendary singer [Ahmad Zahir](/wiki/Ahmad_Zahir "Ahmad Zahir") (1972).

All five non-English sets of lyrics were also recorded by
[Dalida](/wiki/Dalida "Dalida") and [Sandie Shaw](/wiki/Sandie_Shaw "Sandie
Shaw"), with Shaw recording the English lyrics as well.

The UK and United States recording's B-side was [Pete
Seeger](/wiki/Pete_Seeger "Pete Seeger")'s "[Turn! Turn!
Turn!](/wiki/Turn!_Turn!_Turn! "Turn! Turn! Turn!")", which had been a United
States number-one hit for [The Byrds](/wiki/The_Byrds "The Byrds") in 1965.

"Those Were the Days" was catalogue number APPLE 2 (the APPLE 1 number had
been given to an unreleased version of "[The Lady Is a
Tramp](/wiki/The_Lady_Is_a_Tramp "The Lady Is a Tramp")" by [Frank
Sinatra](/wiki/Frank_Sinatra "Frank Sinatra"), recorded specially in 1968, for
[Maureen Starkey](/wiki/Maureen_Starkey_Tigrett "Maureen Starkey Tigrett")'s
22nd birthday, as a gift from [Ringo Starr](/wiki/Ringo_Starr "Ringo Starr"),
under the name of "The Lady is a Champ"). It was the second single to be
released on the Apple label, the first — "Hey Jude" by the Beatles —had
retained the sequential catalogue numbers used by
[Parlophone](/wiki/Parlophone "Parlophone") (in the UK) and
[Capitol](/wiki/Capitol_Records "Capitol Records") (in the US).

Hopkin's version was released on the back of her success on the television
talent show _[Opportunity Knocks](/wiki/Opportunity_Knocks_\(UK_TV_series\)
"Opportunity Knocks \(UK TV series\)")_ , and around the time of its release
popular singer Sandie Shaw was also asked to record the song by her
management, feeling that it should be done by a "real" singer. Shaw's version
was released as a single, but did not match the success of Hopkin's version.

At the peak of the song's success, a New York company used the melody in a
commercial for Rokeach [gefilte fish](/wiki/Gefilte_fish "Gefilte fish"),
arguing that the tune was an old Russian folk-tune and thus in the public
domain. (The commercial included the line "The perfect dish, Rokeach Gefilte
Fish" where the English-language song would go "Those were the days, oh yes,
those were the days.") Raskin successfully sued and won a settlement, since he
had slightly altered the tune to fit his lyrics and had taken out the valid
new copyright.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In the mid-1970s, after Hopkin's contract with Apple ended, "Those Were the
Days" and "Goodbye" were re-recorded with producer [Tony
Visconti](/wiki/Tony_Visconti "Tony Visconti"), whom she had married in 1971.
These re-recorded versions can be found on music compilations.

On 25 October 2010, Apple Records released _[Come and Get It: The Best of
Apple Records](/wiki/Come_and_Get_It:_The_Best_of_Apple_Records "Come and Get
It: The Best of Apple Records")_ , which included the original recordings of
"Those Were the Days" and "Goodbye". The greatest hits compilation album
contained songs by artists signed to the Beatles' Apple record label between
1968 and 1973, the first such multi-artist Apple compilation.

On Christmas 1975, the President of [Equatorial
Guinea](/wiki/Equatorial_Guinea "Equatorial Guinea"), [Francisco Macías
Nguema](/wiki/Francisco_Mac%C3%ADas_Nguema "Francisco Macías Nguema"), had 150
alleged coup plotters executed in the national stadium while a band played
"Those Were the Days".[13]

  * 1959 (1959): [Theodore Bikel](/wiki/Theodore_Bikel "Theodore Bikel") recorded this song, in the original [Russian language](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language").[14]
  * 1962 (1962): American folk group [The Limeliters](/wiki/The_Limeliters "The Limeliters") released the song on a 1962 LP called _Folk Matinee_. This recording was later reissued on a 1968 album.[15]
  * 1968 (1968): The French version of the song, "[Le temps des fleurs](/wiki/Le_temps_des_fleurs_\(album\) "Le temps des fleurs \(album\)")", was popularized by the international recording star [Dalida](/wiki/Dalida "Dalida"). She also recorded the song in Italian and German.
  * 1968 (1968): The Hungarian recording star [Teri Harangozó](/wiki/Teri_Harangoz%C3%B3 "Teri Harangozó") recorded the Hungarian version "Azok a szép napok"[16] and had a huge hit in Hungary, and Hungarian minorities in the neighbourhood countries of Hungary with this song.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * 1968 (1968): The international recording star [Vicky Leandros](/wiki/Vicky_Leandros "Vicky Leandros") recorded the French version "Le temps des fleurs"[16] and had a huge hit in Japan, Canada, and Greece with this song. Mary Hopkin's version was released as "**Kanashiki Tenshi** " (悲しき天使, literally "Sad Angel") in [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan").
  * 1969 (1969): Gene & Francesca recorded the song on their album _Hello Love_ on Tetragrammaton.[17]
  * 1969 (1969): [Chris Connor](/wiki/Chris_Connor "Chris Connor") recorded the song for her album _Softly and Swingin '_ which was released only in Japan. The track was left off the final album release. Connor's estate preserved an original master tape of this album on cassette which includes this track and the track "[Didn't We?](/wiki/Didn%27t_We%3F "Didn't We?")"
  * 1969 (1969): [Bing Crosby](/wiki/Bing_Crosby "Bing Crosby") recorded the song for his album _[Hey Jude / Hey Bing!](/wiki/Hey_Jude_/_Hey_Bing! "Hey Jude / Hey Bing!")_[18]
  * 1969 (1969): [Roger Whittaker](/wiki/Roger_Whittaker "Roger Whittaker") recorded the song for his album _This Is Roger Whittaker_[19]
  * In the 1960s: [Mary Hopkin](/wiki/Mary_Hopkin "Mary Hopkin") and [Sandie Shaw](/wiki/Sandie_Shaw "Sandie Shaw") also sang the song in French, as well as in Italian, Spanish and German. Both Shaw's and Hopkin's versions were released roughly around the same time, as a sort of competition between the two, to see whose single would fare better with the public. When Hopkin's album, _[Postcard](/wiki/Postcard_\(album\) "Postcard \(album\)")_ , was re-released on CD, the Spanish and Italian versions of the songs appeared as bonus tracks. Sandie Shaw has had all of her versions re-released on separate CDs, split up by language.
  * 1974 (1974): [Gigliola Cinquetti](/wiki/Gigliola_Cinquetti "Gigliola Cinquetti") in spain: "Aquellos fueron los dias" from the record "Los mas grandes exitos de Gigliola Cinquetti, Vol. 2
  * 1992: Finnish rock band [Leningrad Cowboys](/wiki/Leningrad_Cowboys "Leningrad Cowboys") included the song on their album _[We Cum from Brooklyn](/wiki/We_Cum_from_Brooklyn "We Cum from Brooklyn")_ and also released it as a single.
  * 1995 (1995): [Cynthia Lennon](/wiki/Cynthia_Lennon "Cynthia Lennon")
  * 2005 (2005): Il Folklorista recorded "Those Were the Days"; Il Folklorista is a project by [Gigi D'Agostino](/wiki/Gigi_D%27Agostino "Gigi D'Agostino") and Luca Noise. The remix was included in the compilation albums _[Disco Tanz](/wiki/Disco_Tanz "Disco Tanz")_ and 2006s _[Some Experiments](/wiki/Some_Experiments "Some Experiments")_.[20]
  * 2005 (2005): American country singer-songwriter [Dolly Parton](/wiki/Dolly_Parton "Dolly Parton") recorded an album including folk and pop songs from the 1960s and 1970s. This was the opening song and title track to her album _[Those Were The Days](/wiki/Those_Were_the_Days_\(Dolly_Parton_album\) "Those Were the Days \(Dolly Parton album\)")_. Mary Hopkin provided backing vocals to this recording.
  * 2007 (2007): Jamaican [dancehall](/wiki/Dancehall "Dancehall") artist [Shaggy](/wiki/Shaggy_\(musician\) "Shaggy \(musician\)") put the refrain of "Those Were the Days" in his album _[Intoxication](/wiki/Intoxication_\(album\) "Intoxication \(album\)")_.
  * 2007 (2007): Latvian instrumental cello rock trio [Melo-M](/wiki/Melo-M "Melo-M") included a version in their 2007 album _[Singalongs](/wiki/Singalongs_\(album\) "Singalongs \(album\)")_.[21]
  * 2007 (2007): Japanese vocalist [Noriko Mitose](/wiki/Noriko_Mitose "Noriko Mitose") included a version on her 2007 album _Cotton_ , entitled "**Hana no Kisetsu** " (花の季節, literally "Flower Season", itself a translation of "Les temps des fleurs"). The arrangement is provided by guitarist [Tomohiko Kira](/wiki/Tomohiko_Kira "Tomohiko Kira").[22]
  * 2008 (2008): [Bad Boys Blue](/wiki/Bad_Boys_Blue "Bad Boys Blue") covered the song on their album [Heart & Soul](/wiki/Heart_%26_Soul_\(Bad_Boys_Blue_album\) "Heart & Soul \(Bad Boys Blue album\)").
  * 2010 (2010): [Wilfredo](/wiki/Wilfredo_\(character\) "Wilfredo \(character\)"), the comic alter ego of the British comedian [Matt Roper](/wiki/Matt_Roper "Matt Roper"), performed the song at the Salento Festival, Italy.[23]
  * 2011 (2011): The Iranian rock band [Kiosk](/wiki/Kiosk_\(band\) "Kiosk \(band\)") recorded this song on their 2011 album _Outcome of Negotiations_.[24]
  * 2013 (2013): Australian country artist Nia Robertson recorded the song on her album _The Woman I Am_.[25]
